entry.title: Build and Deploy a Full-Stack SAP CAPM App with Fiori UI on SAP BTP Cloud Foundry
entry.content:
Build and Deploy a Full-Stack SAP CAP Application with Fiori UI on BTP Cloud Foundry ‚Äì A Complete Guide.

The Cloud Application Programming (CAP) model by SAP is a robust, opinionated framework that simplifies the creation of enterprise-grade services and applications that are scalable, extensible, and cloud-ready. In this in-depth guide, we walk you through every step of building a full-stack CAP project from the ground up using SAP Business Application Studio (BAS). You'll enhance it with a Fiori UI and deploy the entire application stack to SAP Business Technology Platform (SAP BTP) on Cloud Foundry. This guide is crafted with detailed, beginner-friendly explanations and valuable insights for intermediate developers aiming to master modern SAP application development.

 ==Prerequisites and Initial Setup==

 Before we begin, ensure you have an SAP BTP trial or productive account with the necessary entitlements, including SAP HANA Cloud, SAP Build Work Zone (Standard Edition), and SAP Business Application Studio (BAS). These are essential for developing, deploying, and running CAP applications with Fiori UI on Cloud Foundry.

=== Creating a SAP HANA Cloud Instance===

To persist and manage data in your CAP application, you need to provision a SAP HANA Cloud instance in your BTP subaccount.

1.Log in to the SAP BTP Cockpit using your credentials.

2.Navigate into your global account and select the appropriate subaccount.

3.Under the navigation pane, click on "Service Marketplace" to view the available services.

4.Search for "SAP HANA Cloud" and click on it when it appears in the search results.

5.Click on the "Create" button to begin provisioning a new HANA database instance.

 

  1. Accessing SAP HANA Cloud Central
  2. Create New SAP HANA Cloud Instance

 

8.Sign-In with cloud foundry account and select your space from the dropdown

9.üîê Administrator Section

During SAP HANA Cloud instance creation, you‚Äôll need to configure administrative access:

  • Administrator Username: Pre-filled as DBADMIN (not editable)
  • Administrator Password: Enter a strong, secure password
  • Confirm Password: Re-enter the password to confirm

 

 

üîíNote: The DBADMIN password expires every 180 days. Be sure to set a reminder to update it before expiration to avoid access issues

 

10.Configure SAP HANA Database Settings

  • Available Memory Range: In the trial version, it's fixed at 16 GB.

11.SAP HANA Database Advanced Setting

üåêNetwork & Connectivity Settings

  • Allow All IP Addresses
  • Enable this option to allow unrestricted access to the database from any IP address.

üîóEnable Cloud Connector (Optional)

If your application or data sources require secure access to on-premise systems via the SAP Cloud Connector:

  • Toggle Enable Cloud Connector to ON
  • This allows secure integration between your SAP HANA Cloud instance and on-premise environments

 

12.Final Review and Create Instance

After configuring all the necessary settings ‚Äî including instance name, memory size, admin credentials, network access, and optional Cloud Connector ‚Äî take a moment to carefully:

 

  • Review the Administrator Username and Password
  • Verify Connectivity Settings (e.g., Allow All IP Addresses)
  • Confirm the Cloud Connector status (enabled or disabled)
  • Ensure there are no missing or incorrect entries

Once everything looks correct, click Create to start provisioning your SAP HANA Cloud instance.

 

‚è≥The process may take a few minutes. After successful creation, the status will change to Running ‚Äî your database is now ready for use!

 

 

  1. Steps to Manage Configuration and Instance Mapping in SAP HANA Cloud
  • Click ‚ÄúManage Configuration‚Äù:
  • Go to ‚ÄúInstance Mapping‚Äù:
  • Provide Cloud Foundry Environment Details:
  • Set the Environment to: Cloud Foundry
  • Click review and save

 

== 1. Creating a Dev Space in SAP Business Application Studio ==

  1. Open your browser and navigate to the SAP Business Application Studio.
  2. On the landing page, click on the "Create Dev Space" button, which will prompt you to select a template.
  3. From the available options, choose "Full-Stack Cloud Application" as it comes pre-configured with essential tools for CAP and Fiori development.
  4. Assign a recognizable name to your dev space, for example, capm-book-app, to easily identify it later.
  5. Check the box labeled "SAP HANA Tools" to enable support for creating and managing HANA database artifacts.
  6. Click on "Create Dev Space" and wait patiently for the status of the space to change to "RUNNING."
  7. Once the dev space is up and running, click on it to launch the integrated development environment where you will build your application.

 

2.Step-by-Step: Creating a New CAP Project from Template

  • Open SAP Business Application Studio (BAS)
  • Log in to your trial or productive BAS workspace.

2.1 Open the Command Palette

  • Click on the View menu ‚Üí Find Command
  • Or press F1 or Ctrl + Shift + P to open the Command Palette

2.3 Choose   New   Project   from Template

  • From the list, choose:  "CAP Project" (Cloud Application Programming Model)
  • Click Next

2.3 Fill Project Details

  • Project Name: e.g., bookshop
  • Choose Runtime: Node.js
  • Choose  Add  Samples   Yes (optional, useful for beginners)
  • Click  Finish

 

 

2.4 . Open in Workspace

  • If prompted: Click "Open in New Workspace"
  • The wizard will scaffold a full CAP project structure with:

== Modeling Data and Defining Services ==

  1. Define the Data Model

Create a new CDS file in the db folder, typically named data-model.cds:

 3.1 Add Sample Data in CSV Format

Create a new CSV file inside the db/data directory named my.bookshop-Books.csv:

   ID,title,stock,author

  1,The Pragmatic Programmer,42,Andrew Hunt

  2,Clean Code,37,Robert C. Martin

  3,Domain-Driven Design,15,Eric Evans

 4,Introduction to Algorithms,21,Thomas H. Cormen

 5,Design Patterns,18,Erich Gamma

 6,Refactoring,25,Martin Fowler

7,The Clean Coder,30,Robert C. Martin

8,Head First Design Patterns,40,Eric Freeman

9,Working Effectively with Legacy Code,10,Michael Feathers

10,Continuous Delivery,12,Jez Humble

                                                                  

3.2 Define a CAP Service

Inside the  srv  folder, create a service definition file named catalog-service.cds:

3.3 @odata.draft.enabled ‚Äì CAPM Annotation:

  • The @odata.draft.enabled annotation enables draft handling for an entity in SAP CAP (Cloud Application Programming Model). It supports Fiori Elements UIs by allowing users to create, update, save drafts, and finalize records without writing custom CRUD logic.
  • Adds special fields: IsActiveEntity, HasDraftEntity, HasActiveEntity.
  •  

  ‚ö†Ô∏è Notes:

¬∑       Only works with OData V4.

 

 

3.4 Steps to Add a Fiori App Using SAP Fiori Generator:

  • Click File ‚Üí New Project from Template
  • Select ‚ÄúSAP Fiori Application‚Äù and click Start
  •  Select ‚ÄúSAP Fiori Elements‚Äù

3.5 selecting the List Report Page template is a great choice for generating a powerful UI automatically from your CAP service.

  • The List Report Page is part of Fiori Elements, used to create a master-detail UI where

 

3.6 Choose Data Source and service selection :

  • If your CAP project is open in the same workspace
  • Use a local CAP project
  • Select Main Service Entity

 

3.7 After UI setup is finished:

Install dependencies
In your project root directory, run:

  •   npm install

 3.8 Start the CAP server with watch mode
Run:

  •     cds watch
  •   Starts your CAP service locally
  •  Automatically reloads when you make changes to .Cds, .js, or .json files

== 4. Configuring for SAP HANA and cloud foundary Deployment ==

CAP defaults to SQLite for local development, but to deploy on SAP BTP, you must configure it to use SAP HANA.

4.1  Add HANA configuration for production:

4.2  Adds XSUAA (SAP Authorization and Trust Management) to your project

  • Adding oauth2-configuration to xs-security.json for Local & CF Integration
  • Purpose Defines allowed callback URLs for authentication Allows redirect after deployment to Cloud Foundry (US10 region).

4.3 Add HTML5 Repo to Your Project:

  1. Adds configuration to support deploying UI modules (React, Fiori

  1. Updates the mta.yaml file to include:
  • html5-repo-host
  • html5-repo-runtime

 Enables deployment to SAP Launchpad / Work Zone or directly via managed app router

4.4 Adds an App Router to your CAP project for production deployment on SAP BTP Cloud Foundry.

1. The Application Router (Approuter) is a Node.js-based component that.

2.Routes requests to your CAP services (srv) and HTML5 apps (app).

3.Once deployed, the App Router becomes the single entry point URL for your entire application.

4.5 Adds mta.yaml file to your CAP project to enable deployment to SAP BTP Cloud Foundry using the Multi-Target Application (MTA) approach.

  • Creates the deployment descriptor required by Cloud Foundry
  • Combines your DB, service, UI, XSUAA, and HTML5 repo into one .mtar file
  • Manages Dependencies Links services like HANA, XSUAA, Approuter, and HTML5 apps together in one file.

  • Modules ‚Äî what your app is made of
  • These are the individual deployable components (e.g., backend, UI, approuter).
  • Resources ‚Äî external services your app uses
  • These are external backing services or dependencies your modules need.

4.6 Add workzone-standard  Launch your CAP app via a tile on SAP Work Zone standard edition

  • Adds a Work Zone module to your mta.yaml
  • This prepares the app for deployment to Work Zone.
  • Generates a manifest.json for Work Zone
  • Used to register the application (title, URL, etc.).

 

4.7 Install all necessary project dependencies:

4.8 Add Multi-Target Application Builder It comes from the SAP MTA SDK and builds all modules and combines them into a single .mtar file.

4.9 Deploy MTAR Archive to Cloud Foundry

  • The "Build and Deploy Completed" pop-up message appears after you build and deploy your CAPM or MTA project using SAP Business Application Studio or the CLI.

4.10 After deploying your MTA (.mtar) to Cloud Foundry, the application URL(s) become available in the Cloud Foundry space where you deployed.

 

 

Navigate to Your Destination in BTP Cockpit

  • View Your Configured Destinations
  • Test the destination (click on it ‚Üí press "Check Connection")
  • Edit credentials, token URL, client ID/secret

4.11 After deploying an HTML5 application (like a Fiori or React app) to SAP BTP (Cloud Foundry) using html5-repo, the application URL becomes available

 

4.12 Access Your Deployed HDI Container in HANA Database Explorer:

  • In HANA Cloud Central, select your HANA DB instance
  • Click "Open in SAP HANA Database Explorer"
  • Open Database Explorer Add and open your HDI container Explore your tables and data.
  •  Add Your HDI Container
  • In Database Explorer, click the + icon in the left panel (next to ‚ÄúFilter Instances‚Äù)
  • Select:
  • Your Subaccount
  • Cloud Foundry Space
  • Your deployed HDI container (e.g., bookshop_app-db_hdi-container)
  • Click OK
  • Now your HDI container will appear in the left sidebar.

 

 

  • Open and Explore Tables
  • Click on "Tables"
  • Locate your table, e.g., MY_BOOKSHOP_BOOKS
  •  Right-click or double-click the table ‚Üí Open Data

 

Conclusion:

   You now have a fully working SAP BTP full-stack application using CAPM + Fiori UI deployed on Cloud Foundry.

   Feel free to comment or reach out if you need help or enhancements.

entry.title: My AI Experience Sharing - Setting up Joule for the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition (C: Deinstall)
entry.content:
Introduction

Now Artificial Intelligence (AI) is on every professional‚Äôs mind. Everybody wants to be on the bandwagon.  I plan to write a series of blogs on this topic under a big umbrella ‚ÄúMy AI Experience Sharing‚Äù.  This is the first mini-series: setting up Joule for the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition. 

I purposely delayed my action on setting up a Joule to wait for the dust settling down during the Early Adopter phase. The intention paid off but still won‚Äôt give me a free pass üòâ. There are five credible references available as listed in the Reference section, but none of them give you a good explanation on Why, especially on What in a critical step with a readable picture when you desperately need a hint.  To help all the people like me, this blog will focus on explaining those steps, what to enter, and possible mistakes to avoid. 

Note 1: The content here is drawn from my direct experience from setting up Joule for the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition (more than five times and still counting). It might be true for other SAP solutions but only use that as a reference so that I don‚Äôt feel the pressure of entire SAP world on my shoulder üòÅ.

Note 2: Since there are a lot of topics to discuss, I divided the mini-series into Part A Preparation,  Part B Joule Installation and Part C Deinstallation. 

Note 3: The systems I used in this mini-series are:

  • BTP Global Account: 2024-09 3SL Account
  • BTP Joule Subaccount: PSCC-AMER-3SL-PRD
  • SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Production tenant G4X/100, http://myxxxxxxx.s4hana.cloud.sap/ 
  • Cloud Identity Services: Provisioned together with above BTP and Public Cloud tenants, xxxxxxxx.accounts.ondemand.com

Note 4: Considering some customers and consultants need to deinstall and reinstall Joule for many reasons like practicing the installation, correcting an unsuccessful installation, etc., I am adding a new blog Part C: Deinstallation here for your reference.

 

Thirteen Major Joule Deinstallation Steps

Deinstallation is relatively easy. I list these steps in the below figure so that you can cleanly remove all the components in three systems, namely the Business Technology Platform (BTP), the S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition (S/4) and the Cloud Identity Services (CIS).

Thirteen Steps to Remove Joule Installations

 

References

  1. Blog 1: Joule ‚Äì End-to-End Setup Guide (for all Line of Business) Unified Approach
  2. Blog 2: Joule in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition - Setup Guide
  3. Discovery Center 1: Establish a Unified Joule Instance
  4. Discovery Center 2: Activate Joule with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition
  5. SAP Help: Joule onboarding guide
  6. My Blog: My AI Experience Sharing ‚Äì Setting up Joule for the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition (Part A Preparation)
  7. My Blog: My AI Experience Sharing ‚Äì Setting up Joule for the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition (Part B Joule Installation)
  8. My Blog: My AI Experience Sharing ‚Äì Setting up Joule for the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition (Part C Joule Deinstallation)

entry.title: Application Frontend Service now generally available in SAP BTP Trail Account [cf us10-XXX]
entry.content:
As part of our exciting  SAP Build release, we're happy to announce the release of Application Frontend service, a new SaaS application on SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) Trail account for US region for hosting, serving and operating frontend applications.

SAP BTP Trial accounts can be deployed with limited to five(5) applications per subaccount.

Now, you can enjoy the following benefits of Application Frontend Service

What is Application Frontend Service?

Host, serve, and manage frontend applications to extend SAP business solutions.

Application Frontend service lets you host and serve frontend applications. It serves as a single entry point for hosting web-based UI applications to extend SAP's business solutions. The service provides tools for deploying and managing applications, serving static resources, routing backend calls to defined targets, and observability tools.

Application Frontend service is included in the SAP Build.

Application Frontend service supports various channels for managing applications, such as the commonly used Generic Application Content Deployer (GACD) for multitarget applications (MTA), a dedicated UI in the cockpit, and a CLI. These options allow you to choose the channel that best suits your needs.

Application Frontend is a SaaS application which is not coupled to any specific SAP BTP runtime environment or other SAP BTP applications. You can find and subscribe to the service from the SAP BTP cockpit. Application Frontend is also equipped with a service broker to support interaction flows using service instances, for example when using MTA deploy in the CF environment. 

While there is native support in the good old MTA concept for lifecycle management, Application Frontend also provides a command line interface (CLI) as a first-class tool for managing your applications. With the CLI, you can directly interact with the service and execute all actions supported by Application Frontend to enjoy fast response times and new integration opportunities.

High Level Overview of Application Frontend Service - Deployment

Prerequisites to enable Application Frontend Serivce

  • Go to your SAP BTP Trail Account - Subaccount
  • Go to your Instance and Subscription - Subscribe for SAP Cloud Identity Services
  • Enable SAP IAS and Trust & Auth with enabled SAP IAS
  • Go to Entitlements - Select Application Frontend Service
  • Select 2 checkbox for enabling the Plan (Developer and Application) 
  • Create a Role Collections and Assign to your User (SAP IAS enabled)

Go to Instances and Subscription - Select Application Frontend Service from dropdown with Plan - Trial

Go to Instances and Subscription - Select Application Frontend Service with Plan - Developer

Create a New Role Collection

Assign Role to newly created Role Collection

Application Frontend Service Library & CLI (Command Line)

npm install -g /appfront-cli

afctl login --sso -a <api_endpoint>

afctl push

 

Conclusion

Application Frontend Service is a game-changer for Cloud Foundry users. By simplifying UI development, enhancing scalability, and promoting consistency, AFS empowers developers to create high-quality applications more efficiently. As cloud-native development continues to evolve, integrating tools like AFS will be crucial in staying ahead of the curve and delivering exceptional user experiences.

For more detailed insights, you can check out the original blog posts : 

  • Introducing Application Frontend Service : Application Frontend Service 
  • Simple UI Applications with Application Frontend Service : DEV Community
  • Application Frontend Service Help Documentation : Guide and Development
  • Application Frontend Service Onboarding Service -  AppFront trial on-boarding help page

entry.title: A Comprehensive Guide to Transition from SAP Build Work Zone, standard edition to advanced edition
entry.content:
As organizations evolve, the need for more integrated digital workplace solutions becomes paramount. SAP Build Work Zone offers two distinct editions to cater to varying organizational needs: the standard edition and the advanced edition. While the standard edition provides a centralized access point to multiple SAP systems, the advanced edition extends these capabilities by empowering business users. This guide aims to facilitate a seamless transition from the standard to the advanced edition, ensuring that your organization can fully harness the enhanced features of the advanced edition.

Understanding the Differences

Before embarking on the transition, it's essential to comprehend the key distinctions between the two editions to make the most of the expanded set of capabilities in advanced:

  • SAP Build Work Zone, standard edition: Formerly known as SAP Launchpad service, this edition provides a central access point to multiple SAP cloud and on-premise applications, processes & tasks via different ‚Äòapplication site‚Äô. It also offers different customization and extension capabilities. 

SAP Build Work Zone, advanced edition extends the capabilities of the standard edition by empowering business users to create, manage, and publish their own content. It also offers a broader set of widgets for more flexible workpage building. Users can also create interactive communities, known as workspaces, with document access, discussion forums, knowledge base, task collaboration & more.

The following visual offers a more detailed comparison, expanded feature set of the SAP Build Work Zone, advanced edition. 

Subscription and Service Plan differences

  • SAP Build Work Zone, standard edition is often bundled with certain SAP cloud solutions (such as SAP S/4HANA Cloud), providing a streamlined setup for foundational portal and page-building use cases. It supports both subscription-based and consumption-based licensing models, making it suitable for customers seeking fast onboarding with minimal complexity. You can find more details here.
  • On the other hand, SAP Build Work Zone, advanced edition is a standalone, premium offering that unlocks enterprise-grade capabilities. It requires a separate license and subscription that follows a follows a consumption-based commercial model. Read more here.

Transition Steps

Transitioning from the standard to the advanced edition involves several critical steps: 

1. Assess current implementation

Begin by thoroughly evaluating your existing SAP Build Work Zone, standard edition setup. Document all active sites, pages, applications, and integrations. Identify any custom developments, branding elements, or specific configurations that are crucial for replication or adaptation in the advanced edition.

2. Plan the transition

Establish clear objectives for the transition, such as enhancing user engagement or improving content management. Engage key stakeholders, including IT teams, business users, and content creators, to gather requirements and address potential concerns.

3. Exporting content from standard edition

It's crucial to export your existing content from standard edition to facilitate a smooth transition to the advanced edition. In the Site Directory, select the desired site, click on 'More Options', and choose 'Export Site' to download the site and its content as a ZIP file. This export includes the site's structure, pages, and associated applications, ensuring that essential components are preserved for import into the advanced edition.

4. Set up the advanced edition environment

It is possible to subscribe to both SAP Build Work Zone, standard and advanced editions within the same subaccount. This makes it easier to set up the advanced edition without disrupting your current standard edition setup.

To get started, subscribe to SAP Build Work Zone, advanced edition through the SAP BTP Cockpit. Configure user authentication and provisioning using SAP Cloud Identity Services (Identity Authentication and Identity Provisioning) to ensure secure and efficient user management.

Use the SAP Build Work Zone, advanced edition booster to automate many of the initial setup steps in your subaccount. In addition to the booster, advanced edition requires a set of 'configurator' steps to be completed. These are essential for enabling full functionality of the service (and are not required or present in the standard edition). These steps typically include setting up roles, permissions, and other advanced configurations tailored to the edition‚Äôs extended capabilities.

5. Content migration

Since there is no fully automated upgrade or migration flow from the standard to the advanced edition, manual intervention is required. To ease the transition, you can export most of the content from the standard edition and import it into the advanced edition. This process involves the following steps:

  • Exporting the necessary content from the standard edition (as described above)
  • Importing the content to advanced edition

This approach allows for optimization and restructuring where needed. Additionally, leveraging the advanced edition's capabilities, such as interactive workspaces and enhanced page-building tools, can enrich the user experience.

6. Reusing existing configurations

When subscribing to the advanced edition within the same subaccount, certain configurations can be seamlessly reused. BTP destinations, Cloud Connector configurations, and custom applications remain intact and do not require (full) reconfiguration.

If your organization utilizes a custom domain, this can significantly ease the transition from a user perspective. For example, a custom domain that previously pointed to your standard edition site can now be reconfigured to point to the new advanced edition site. This allows users to continue accessing the Work Zone through their existing bookmarks and saved links without disruption. It ensures continuity and minimizes confusion during the switch, while maintaining consistent access points throughout the transition.

7. Best practices

To ensure a smooth transition it's advisable to first perform all migration and configuration activities in a non-production environment, such as a development or testing subaccount. This approach allows for thorough testing, validation of configurations, and identification of potential issues without impacting the live production environment. Once the transition process has been successfully tested and refined in these lower environments, you can confidently replicate the steps in the production subaccount, minimizing the risk of disruptions to end-users.

8. Testing and validation

Conduct thorough User Acceptance Testing (UAT) with a group of end-users to ensure all functionalities work as intended and meet business requirements. Evaluate the system's performance under typical load conditions to identify and address any potential issues.

9. Change management

Develop and deliver training sessions to familiarize users with the new features and interfaces of the advanced edition. Provide documentation, FAQs, and support channels to assist users during the transition period.

10. Go-live

Execute the transition plan, ensuring minimal disruption to daily operations. Continuously monitor the system for any issues and gather user feedback to make necessary adjustments.

Conclusion

This transition can significantly enhance your organization's digital workplace capabilities. By following a structured approach and leveraging the advanced features, you can create a more engaging and efficient user experience. It can empower your teams with the tools they need to collaborate effectively and drive business success.

Hope this blogpost will support your transition journey. We‚Äôll be following up shortly with a detailed how-to guide to help you through the process. 

For more detailed information consider exploring the following:

  • SAP Help Portal: Getting Started with SAP Build Work Zone
  • SAP Build Work Zone on: sap.com / SAP Community
  • SAP Learning Journeys:  Implement and Administer SAP Build Work Zone

entry.title: SAP Fiori Deployment in 2025: Embedded vs. Work Zone Standard vs. Advanced Edition
entry.content:
As SAP advances its strategy toward a unified and intelligent user experience, organizations are increasingly required to re-evaluate their SAP Fiori deployment models. Traditional architectures, such as the Central Hub, are being phased out in favor of more modern, cloud-based solutions like SAP Build Work Zone‚Äîavailable in both Standard and Advanced editions.

This shift presents a strategic decision point for IT leaders: selecting the most appropriate deployment model that aligns with their existing system landscape, integration needs, and long-term digital goals. Understanding the strengths and trade-offs of Embedded Fiori, Work Zone Standard, and Work Zone Advanced is essential for designing a scalable and user-centric enterprise environment.

This guide compares all three modern deployment approaches so you can make an informed, future-proof decision.

Option 1: Embedded Deployment (Frontend + Backend in S/4HANA)

What it is: Fiori frontend server and Launchpad are embedded directly into the SAP S/4HANA system.

Best for:

  • Greenfield S/4HANA implementations
  • Simpler landscapes with no need to federate apps from multiple sources

Pros:

  • Simplified architecture
  • Lower total cost of ownership
  • Direct and efficient performance
  • No additional BTP subscription needed

Cons:

  • Not ideal for hybrid system landscapes (e.g., ECC + S/4)
  • Downtime impacts entire stack
  • Limited flexibility for UI extensions or content aggregation

Option 2: SAP Build Work Zone, Standard Edition
(Successor to Central Hub deployment)

What it is: A cloud-based launchpad-as-a-service running on SAP BTP. Provides centralized access to apps and content from multiple SAP systems.

Best for:

  • Customers with hybrid environments (e.g., ECC, S/4HANA, CRM)
  • Users needing a unified Launchpad across systems

Pros:

  • Aggregates apps from multiple systems
  • Personalizable Launchpad (cards, themes, roles)
  • Prebuilt integration with SAP apps like Ariba, SuccessFactors, and Concur
  • Low-code extensibility with SAP Build tools
  • Lower entry point than Advanced edition

Cons:

  • Limited support for advanced workflows or custom page layouts
  • Less extensibility for 3rd-party or custom content
  • No native document management or microsite capabilities

Option 3: SAP Build Work Zone, Advanced Edition
(For full digital experience and enterprise portal replacement)

What it is: An enterprise-grade digital workplace platform built on SAP BTP + SAP Launchpad + SAP Work Zone + SAP Build Pages + SAP Knowledge Base. It replaces traditional SAP Enterprise Portal and delivers full-scale intranet functionality.

Best for:

  • Customers replacing SAP Enterprise Portal
  • Organizations needing to integrate SAP and non-SAP apps
  • Use cases requiring business content, collaboration, workflows, and knowledge-sharing

Pros:

  • Advanced page builder for intranet-like UX
  • Deep integration with Microsoft 365, Teams, SharePoint, and 3rd-party systems
  • Role-based content delivery with custom navigation layouts
  • Embedded SAP Task Center, Process Automation, Knowledge Base
  • Ideal for large, multi-LOB organizations

Cons:

  • Higher cost and complexity than Standard edition
  • Requires thoughtful implementation planning
  • Best suited for organizations with mature digital transformation goals

Comparison table:

 

AspectSAP Fiori LaunchpadSAP Work Zone Standard EditionSAP Work Zone Standard Edition
DeploymentOn S/4HANA systemSAP BTPSAP BTP
System Scope1 system (S/4HANA)Multiple SAP systemsSAP + 3rd-party apps
UX FlexibilityBasic LaunchpadLaunchpad + basic cardsFull page editor, custom layouts
CollaborationNoneNonewikis, forums, Teams
Document ManagementNoneNoneAvailable
Task Center / WorkflowNotification Area/Local Workflows (My Inbox)SAP Task CenterEmbedded SAP Task Center
M365 IntegrationNoneNoneAvailable
Use Case FitSimplicity & speedCentral accessFull digital workplace
Ideal ForS/4HANA-only landscapesHybrid SAP appsPortal replacement + collaboration
CostNo additional BTP costMediumHigher

Conclusion

Establishing a unified point of entry for enterprise users is essential to an effective SAP Fiori deployment strategy. Whether an organization operates within a single SAP S/4HANA system or manages a complex, multi-system landscape, selecting the appropriate deployment model ensures enhanced usability, simplified maintenance, and long-term adaptability.

Embedded Fiori is best suited for organizations running a clean, standalone SAP S/4HANA environment. It provides a streamlined, fully self-contained user experience without requiring integration with other SAP or non-SAP systems‚Äîmaking it an efficient and cost-effective option for focused landscapes.

SAP Build Work Zone ‚Äì Standard Edition is recommended for scenarios involving multiple SAP backend systems, such as ECC, CRM, or BW. It serves as a centralized launchpad, delivering a consistent user experience across the enterprise.

SAP Build Work Zone ‚Äì Advanced Edition is ideal for companies seeking to replace SAP Enterprise Portal or establish a robust digital workplace. With capabilities for cross-application integration, collaboration, document management, and connectivity to third-party platforms like Microsoft 365, it supports a modern and extensible enterprise UX.

SAP Build Work Zone‚Äîavailable in both Standard and Advanced Editions‚Äîrepresents the evolution of SAP‚Äôs UX strategy, replacing legacy frontend models with a cloud-native, scalable platform aligned with digital transformation goals.

Ultimately, the deployment choice should reflect the organization's current IT architecture, user requirements, and future roadmap. Aligning SAP Fiori strategy with these considerations enables a future-ready user experience that empowers employees and streamlines system management.

entry.title: SAP Fiori development newsletter July 2025 (issue #35)
entry.content:
Summer is here, bringing hot weather across the U.S. and around the world. SAP is also turning up the temperature with hot new AI-powered innovations, many of which were introduced at Sapphire (see article below). Even more new stuff is planned for TechEd and Devtoberfest in the fall.

For ongoing updates, I encourage you to join our monthly SAP Fiori development roundtable. You can meet online with fellow developers and the SAP engineers who build our professional development tools. Register online or email me for an invitation. Our next meeting is Wednesday, July 9, 2025. 

If you prefer to receive this in your inbox, please subscribe to the SAP Fiori development newsletter.

Development News

Sapphire had great innovations, if you are on public cloud

There were lots of announcements about new innovations for both developers and business users. The question for many customers is when their systems will be current enough to consume them. Read about the two parallel universes ‚Äì one filled with AI in the cloud and the other grounded in legacy code.
https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-blog-posts-by-sap/parallel-universes-the-dual-nature-of-ux-and-ai-among-sap-customers-at/ba-p/14113975

SAP Fiori tools 2506 now available

The 2506 release of SAP Fiori tools includes enhancements that make full-stack development with SAP Fiori elements and RAP even more seamless‚Äîfrom initial app creation to UI adaptation and low-code configuration.
https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/sap-fiori-tools-2506-update-open-source-faster-app-creation-adaptation/ba-p/14131156

AI-powered project accelerator

The AI-powered project accelerator from SAP Fiori tools automates multiple steps, including creating a data model, preparing mock data, building an OData service, generating an SAP Fiori app and adding the necessary annotations. See how to set up a trial account and try it for yourself.
https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/from-idea-to-app-using-ai-powered-project-accelerator-to-develop-sap-fiori/ba-p/14095300

Introducing SAPUI5 version preview in SAP Build Work Zone

We have introduced a new option to preview an upcoming SAPUI5 version for SAP Build Work Zone. This capability aims to provide a controlled environment for evaluating SAPUI5 updates in SAP Build Work Zone, thereby avoiding immediate changes in production environments.
https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/introducing-sapui5-version-preview-in-sap-build-work-zone/ba-p/14117996

Explore SAPUI5 1.136.x-legacy-free for future-proof UI5 apps

SAPUI5 1.136.x-legacy-free deprecated code removed is now available via cloud access. Test your code for future-proof best practices and provide early feedback to the UI5 team.
https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/explore-sapui5-openui5-1-136-x-legacy-free/ba-p/14103271

SAPUI5 is leading the way in accessibility with WCAG 2.2

Accessibility is key to using SAP's business solutions. Adopting the latest standards ensures that solutions are inclusive and meet the diverse needs of users globally. When creating apps with SAP Build and SAPUI5, developers can leverage the latest Web Content Accessibility Guidelines (WCAG).
https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/sapui5-is-leading-the-way-in-accessibility-with-wcag-2-2/ba-p/14101596

SAP Fiori Application Generator available in open source

The SAP Fiori tools team is delighted to announce that the underlying code for the SAP Fiori Application Generator has been moved entirely to open source. This has been a long journey...
https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/sap-fiori-application-generator-available-in-open-source/ba-p/14109021

New SAP Design System portal for SAP Fiori design guidelines

The SAP Design System portal contains everything about the design system, including comprehensive new UI Kits for designers in Figma.
https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/new-sap-design-system-portal-for-sap-fiori-design-guidelines-and-new-ui/ba-p/14109558

Quickly generate and deploy SAP Fiori apps from ABAP Development Tools for Eclipse

The new quick SAP Fiori application generator lets you generate an application based on SAP Fiori elements annotations and deploy the SAP Fiori UI with only a few clicks from the service binding editor in ADT.
https://community.sap.com/t5/application-development-and-automation-blog-posts/quickly-generate-and-deploy-sap-fiori-apps-from-abap-development-tools-for/ba-p/14116822

Events

SAP Fiori Innovation Day Bangalore 

The biggest SAP Fiori Innovation Day ever!
This summary highlights the key sessions, insights from our presentations, and the remarkable contributions from our local development community.
https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-blog-posts-by-sap/sap-fiori-innovation-day-bangalore-connection-gratitude-ai-and-local/ba-p/14129580

SAP Fiori Innovation Day Dallas

  •              October 17 as part of the ASUG chapter meeting
  •              Registration link opening soon - mark your calendar now

SAP Fiori Innovation Day Paris

  •              December 10
  •              Registration link opening soon - mark your calendar now

All our SAP Fiori Innovation Day events are open to customers.
If you are a partner, please let me know if you are interested in sponsoring in one or both of our locations.
I hope you can join us.

SAP TechEd

Registration is now open for both the in-person event in Berlin and the virtual event. Here are details on what you can expect.
https://community.sap.com/t5/sap-teched-blog-posts/sap-teched-2025-registration-is-live-check-out-our-brand-new-hybrid/ba-p/14107573

Back issues from the past year

SAP FIori development newsletter May 2025 (Issue #34)

SAP Fiori development newsletter March 2025 (Issue #33)

SAP Fiori development newsletter January 2025 (issue #32)

SAP Fiori development newsletter November 2024 (issue #31)

SAP Fiori development newsletter September 2024 (issue #30)

SAP Fiori development newsletter July 2024 (issue #29)

entry.title: Simple End to End Application development using SAP Build App
entry.content:
Simple End to End Application development using SAP Build App

Developing extension apps is a very common requirement among clients. Using Fiori application as an extension to SAP BTP was always an option but we can use SAP‚Äôs no code/ low code to develop a basic UI application which will connected to SAP SuccessFactors instance.

We will be developing an application for email search (this is just a basic application).

In the below example, I have used trail BTP account.

SuccessFactors Connectivity

I have created a destination in my trail subaccount to connect to one of my sandbox SF tenants.

 

SAP Build App Configuration

  1. Create a project of type ‚Äì SAP Build Apps ‚Äì web & mobile application

 

 

 

 

 

 2. Once project is created successfully, navigate to auth and data tab to integrate with SAP SuccessFactors

 

Select SF credentials which is created in BTP destination.

 

Search the entity (PerEmail in our case) and click on install integration and enable it.

 

 3. Navigate back to UI Canvas and start design your web page

Drag heading, a text and two cards.

 

 

Change the label accordingly.

 

Select the text field and navigate to content -> formula and write as per below screenshot.

4. Now click on home page on left side and create new pages

 

5. Navigate back to home page -> select email search card -> add logic to card 1

In Properties, search the page on which we want to navigate. Similarly, do for view data card.

 

 

 

 6. Configure search Page

Drag two input fields, a button and a text field for showing output

 

 7. Define variables.

Switch to variables view and in page variables, create PersonId, EmailType and output

 

8. Populate the variables to UI

Select the personId input field and then click on value ->  data and variables -> page variables -> PersonId.

Similarly, do this for email type

 

 

 

 

9. Add logic on button.

In the logic canvas, search for get records and map with component tap. Select ‚Äòget records‚Äô and map the personId and email type variable

 

 

 

 

To populate the output of search in another page variable, map it with set page variable and bind with output of another node

 

 

 

 

 

10. Configure table

Navigate to database screen and add table by searching in the market place

 

 

Click

 

Click on edit configuration and select the fields required in the table

 

 

 

 

Now app is ready to test.

11. Launch and test the application

Click on Launch -> open preview portal -> preview on web

 

 

 

 

 

 

By using the capabilities of SAP build app, final application which I have built looks like below:

Summary: This document outlines the steps to build a basic end-to-end application using SAP Build Apps with a no-code/low-code approach. It demonstrates connecting to a SAP SuccessFactors instance and designing a UI for email search functionality. The app includes variable binding, logic flows, and result display, making it ready for testing through the preview portal. This approach simplifies extension app development on SAP BTP.

entry.title: SAP Build Work Zone, standard edition - New Features released for July 10th
entry.content:
List of New features / enhancements released for July 10 - SAP Build Work Zone, standard edition

1Ô∏è‚É£  App Catalogs Displayed

When using the page editor to add apps to a page, you can now see a list of app catalogs. Selecting a catalog, filters the results and displays only the apps in the selected catalog.

Defining Custom Themes

The Local Entry Point business solution developer guide has been enhanced to include information about how to integrate with the UI Theme Designer service to create and manage custom themes.

Refer Documentation for more details for custom Theme

2Ô∏è‚É£ Display of Site Menu

A new site setting enables the admin to choose how to display the site menu at runtime.

Options are:
  • Side: menu displayed on the side according to language.
  • Top: menu displayed at the top of the screen.
  • Minimized: menu displayed in a collapsed state and can be expanded.

3Ô∏è‚É£ HTML Business Solutions without Destinations

It is now possible to create a content channel for HTML5 business solutions without defining destinations.

In the HTML5 business solution scenario, the content provider on the consumer side can be created by selecting it from a list of subscribed applications or locally deployed applications.

4Ô∏è‚É£ Key User Adaptation Support

The Key User Adaptation site setting is enabled by default for new sites.

Key User Adaptation allows users to make changes at runtime to the user interface of apps from the HTML5 content repository directly in a page without having to write new code.

Turn Toggle to Yes  - allows key users to adapt the UI of HTML5 apps at runtime.

Turn Toggle to off - No - disables this feature.

Result:

The end user will see an Adapt UI entry in the dropdown list of actions in the User Actions menu and they can modify the UI of their app.

For more information, see:

  • Adapting the UI of Different App Types

  • What is UI5 Flexibility for Key Users?

  • Adapting SAP Fiori UIs at Runtime - Key User Adaptation

5Ô∏è‚É£ Read-Only Roles

A new admin read-only role collection has been added to the SAP BTP cockpit to allow support teams to access a subset of the admin environment. This will enable them to investigate issues without being able to change customer data or configurations.

The role name is: Launchpad_Admin_Read_Only.

Support users will see a banner that indicates that they only have read-only access and will not be able to save any changes in the configurations.

entry.title: Developing a Shell Plugin for SAP Build Work Zone to Display Custom Notifications on SAP BTP
entry.content:
Introduction‚ÄÉ

Unlocking Custom Experiences in SAP Build Work Zone: Shell Plugin in Action
In today‚Äôs digital workplace, personalization is key. This article showcases how to enhance SAP Build Work Zone with a custom shell plugin that brings tailored notifications right to the user‚Äôs fingertips. Using a Multi-Target UI5/CAP application, we‚Äôll demonstrate how to create, manage, and surface custom alerts‚Äîseamlessly integrated into your Work Zone experience.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

To replicate this you should have a base knowledge of SAP BTP, JS, SAPUI5 and SAP CAP, I will not go deep down in to how to generate a project in BAS, or create an instance in SAP BTP. 

***GITHUB URL REMOVED BY MODERATION***

Project Architecture

‚ÄÉ

Backend/Frontend App Development:

Generate a regular SAP CAP application

Firstly I've created a primitave data structure under db/schema.cds

namespace my.Notification;

entity Notification {
    key ID : UUID;
    type: String(30);
    title: String;
    message: String;
}

 Than a service at srv/service.cds:

using { my.Notification as my } from '../db/schema';

service NotificationService {
    entity Notification as projection on my.Notification;
}

And the backend is almost done, now add an app router and a sapui5 freestyle base app to the project.

Now let's add a form to create and delete the notifications under app/<app name>/webapp/view/<view name>.view.xml:

 

Spoiler
Remember to correct the controller name if you copy the code

 

<mvc:View
    controllerName="com.sap.shellnotificationsender.controller.MyView"
    xmlns:mvc="sap.ui.core.mvc"
    xmlns="sap.m"
    xmlns:form="sap.ui.layout.form"
    xmlns:core="sap.ui.core">

    <Toolbar>
        <Title text="{i18n>title}" />
    </Toolbar>

    <Shell id="mainShell">
        <VBox class="sapUiSmallMargin">
            <form:SimpleForm
                    editable="true"
                    layout="ResponsiveGridLayout"
                    labelSpanL="1" labelSpanM="2"
                    adjustLabelSpan="false"
                    columnsL="3" columnsM="3"
                    class="sapUiSmallMarginBottom">

                    <Label text="Type" />
                    <ComboBox id="newType" selectedKey="information">
                        <core:Item key="Warning" text="Warning" />
                        <core:Item key="Success" text="Success" />
                        <core:Item key="Information" text="Information" />
                        <core:Item key="Error" text="Error" />
                        <core:Item key="Alert" text="Alert" />
                        <core:Item key="Confirm" text="Confirm" />
                    </ComboBox>

                    <Label text="Title" />
                    <Input id="newTitle" />

                    <Label text="Message" />
                    <Input id="newMessage" />

                    <Label text="" />
                    <Button text="Add Notification"
                        press="onAddNotification"
                        type="Emphasized"/>
                </form:SimpleForm>

            <!-- Table Section -->
            <Table id="shellNotificationsTable" items="{/Notification}">
                <columns>
                    <Column>
                        <Text text="Delete" />
                    </Column>
                    <Column>
                        <Text text="Type" />
                    </Column>
                    <Column>
                        <Text text="Title" />
                    </Column>
                    <Column>
                        <Text text="Message" />
                    </Column>
                </columns>

                <items>
                    <ColumnListItem>
                        <cells>
                            <Button icon="sap-icon://delete" type="Negative" press="deleteRow" />
                            <Text text="{type}" />
                            <Text text="{title}" />
                            <Text text="{message}" />
                        </cells>
                    </ColumnListItem>
                </items>
            </Table>
        </VBox>
    </Shell>
</mvc:View>

As next let's implement the controller that manages the view with all the necessary notification creation/deletion methods:

sap.ui.define([
    "sap/ui/core/mvc/Controller",
    "sap/m/MessageBox",
	"sap/m/MessageToast"
], (Controller, MessageBox, MessageToast) => {
    "use strict";

    return Controller.extend("com.sap.shellnotificationsender.controller.MyView", {
        onInit() {

        },

        deleteRow: function (oEvent) {
			var oContext = oEvent.getSource().getBindingContext().getObject();
			console.log(oContext);
			MessageBox.confirm("Are your sure you want to delete this message?", {
				title: "Confirm",
				onClose: function (sAction) {
					if (sAction === "OK") {
						this.onDeleteSpecificRecord(oContext)
					}
				}.bind(this),
				actions: [
					MessageBox.Action.OK,
					MessageBox.Action.CANCEL
				],
				emphasizedAction: MessageBox.Action.OK
			})
		},

		onDeleteSpecificRecord: function (oRecord) {
			var oDataModel = this.getOwnerComponent().getModel();
			var oBusyDialog = new sap.m.BusyDialog({
				title: "Deleting Record",
				text: "Please Wait ..."
			})
			oBusyDialog.open();
			oDataModel.delete(`/Notification('${oRecord.ID}')`)
				.then(() => {
					console.log("Record deleted successfully");
				})
				.catch((error) => {
					console.error("Deletion failed:", error);
				})
				.finally(() => {
					this.getView().byId("shellNotificationsTable").getBinding("items").refresh();
					oBusyDialog.close();
				});
		},

		onAddNotification: function () {
			const sType = this.byId("newType").getValue();
			const sTitle = this.byId("newTitle").getValue();
			const sMessage = this.byId("newMessage").getValue();

			this.byId("shellNotificationsTable").getBinding("items").create({
				"type": sType,
				"title": sTitle,
				"message": sMessage
			}).created().then(function() {
				MessageToast.show("Created")
			})
		}
    });
});

The last thing to do is to add all the features that you need to the application, like HANA DB, xsuaa in my case, to do so just run

cds add hana
cds add xsuaa

And like this is the app ready, let's deploy it, firstly login to Cloud Foundry

cf login

then right click on the mta.yaml file -> "Build MTA Project"

then go to mta_archives/<archive name>.tar right click and "Deploy MTA Project".

BTP Steps

To connect to the app from the shell plugin you need to create a SAP BTP Destination, 

to do so go to <BTP Subaccount> -> Cloud Foundry -> <Your space> -> <Your app name>-srv and copy it's address, that's your destination URL

Now you need to get the authentication data for the Destination

Go to <Your CF Space> -> Instances -> <Your app name>-auth -> <Your app name>-auth-key 

Copy these:

Client ID, Client secret and url (Access Token URL)

Now go back to your Subaccount and create a new destination with your data:

  • URL:  app-srv URL
  • Authentication: OAuth2ClientCredentials
  • ClientID: ClientID
  • Client secret: Client secret
  • Token service URL type: Dedicated
  • Token Service URL: <Access token URL>/oauth/token

After this add these 2 parameters:

  • HTML5.DynamicDestination: true
  • WebIDEEnabled: true

With this step is the backend development concluded.

Shell Plugin Development:

Firstly a general explanation about shell plugins. Shell Plugins are UI5 Applications that allow to add new Elements to SAP Build Work Zone/Fiori Launchpad like Headers, Footers, menu items etc.

To create a shell plugin generate a plain UI5 Basic Freestyle application with the "Template Wizard" in Business Application Studio.

There are a couple of things to modify in the manifest.json to make a a Shell Plugin:

Inside sap.app change the type to component:

"type": "component"

In sap.app>crossNavigation hide the launcher:

"crossNavigation": {
      "inbounds": {
        "Shell-plugin": {
          "semanticObject": "Shell",
          "action": "plugin",
          "title": "{{Shell-plugin.flpTitle}}",
          "hideLauncher": true,
          "icon": "",
          "signature": {
            "parameters": {},
            "additionalParameters": "allowed"
          }
        }
      }
    },

 Add this part under after sap.cloud:

"sap.flp": {
    "type": "plugin"
  }

  This way the Shell Plugin configuration is completed, now let's add our newly created Destination

in sap.app>dataSources add this:

"NotificationService": {
        "uri": "/ShellNotifications/odata/v4/notification/",
        "type": "OData",
        "settings": {
          "odataVersion": "4.0"
        }
      }

and in sap.ui5>models: 

"Notification": {
        "dataSource": "NotificationService",
        "settings": {
          "synchronizationMode": "None",  
          "operationMode": "Server",
          "autoExpandSelect": true
        },
        "type": "sap.ui.model.odata.v4.ODataModel"
      }

and as last thing add this route to your xs-app.json file:

 

Spoiler
Remember: the order of the routes in xs-app matters, if you add it at the end it might not be resolved correctly by the app router

 

{
      "source": "^/ShellNotifications/(.*)$",
      "destination": "ShellNotifications",
      "target": "$1",
      "authenticationType": "xsuaa",
      "csrfProtection": true
    },

Now finally you can add the code that displays the notifications, to do so open the Component.js file and add the following code to the init method:

const oModel = this.getModel("Notification");

            oModel.bindList("/Notification").requestContexts().then((aContexts) => {
                const aData = aContexts.map(oContext => oContext.getObject());
                for (const el of aData) {
                    const nType = el["type"];
                    const nTitle = el["title"];
                    const nMessage = el["message"]
                    if (nType === "Information") {
                        MessageBox.information(nMessage, {
                            title: nTitle
                        });
                    } else if (nType === "Alert") {
                        MessageBox.alert(nMessage, {
                            title: nTitle
                        })
                    } else if (nType === "Confirm") {
                        MessageBox.confirm(nMessage, {
                            title: nTitle
                        })
                    } else if (nType === "Error") {
                        MessageBox.error(nMessage, {
                            title: nTitle
                        })
                    } else if (nType === "Success") {
                        MessageBox.success(nMessage, {
                            title: nTitle
                        })
                    } else if (nType === "Warning") {
                        MessageBox.warning(nMessage, {
                            title: nTitle
                        })
                    }
                }
            }).catch((err) => {
                console.error("Failed to load notifications:", err);
            });

 And like this is the development finished, the last step is to deploy it and add to WorkZone.

To build it do the same steps as with the MTA app:

  • right click on the mta.yaml file -> "Build MTA Project"
  • go to mta_archives/<archive name>.tar right click and "Deploy MTA Project".

SAP Build Work Zone Steps

Although the SAP Build Work Zone standard and advanced edition have some UI differences, the steps are the same for both of them.

All the steps performed below are done on SAP Build Work Zone advanced edition.

Start by going to the Administration Console -> External Integration -> Business Content -> Content Manager

‚ÄÉThan open the content channel and update the "HTML5 Apps"

‚ÄÉAfter that go Content Explorer and click Content Explorer (In the current UI it's a button in the header)

Select "HTML5 Apps" and add the new Shell Plugin that you just created

‚ÄÉTo be able to see the plugin, assign it to a role, in my case it's the "Everyone" role, you can find it in the Content Manager

‚ÄÉAfter you've done that you should be able to see your new shell plugin the SAP Build Work Zone's launchpad

‚ÄÉIf you don't see it try to open the page in an "Anonymous" Tab and check the developer console

Conclusion

What we‚Äôve built here is just a glimpse into what‚Äôs possible with shell plugins in SAP Build Work Zone. By integrating a custom notification system, we‚Äôve shown how easily you can extend the platform to better fit your customers‚Äô needs. But this is only the starting point.

There‚Äôs a wide range of enhancements you can explore next‚Äîsuch as targeting specific users with personalized notifications, adding actionable buttons to each alert, or even integrating with external systems to trigger real-time messages. The flexibility of shell extensions offers endless opportunities to enrich the Work Zone experience and tailor it to your organization‚Äôs workflows.

So go ahead‚Äîexperiment, extend, and elevate your Work Zone.

entry.title: How Generative‚ÄØAI & LLMs Are Redefining UI Creation
entry.content:
Introduction to User Interfaces (UI)

User interfaces (UI) are everywhere. From simple command-line terminals to mobile layouts, user interfaces (UI) exist to turn abstract goals: ‚Äúsend this message,‚Äù ‚Äúbook that flight,‚Äù and ‚Äúpay this friend‚Äù‚Äîinto visible controls that anyone can understand immediately. 

Currently, at startups and smaller companies, designers pass static mock-ups to developers, who then translate every layer into HTML, CSS, and JS, checking each line against accessibility rules and responsive breakpoints. At larger organizations and enterprises like SAP, designers use no-code and low-code systems like SAP Design System or SAP Build Apps, where users can drag and drop widgets to create websites and UI in general. 

With the recent advance of deep-learning systems and generative AI, especially large-language models like ChatGPT, Gemini, or Claude, promising to disrupt various areas, the ripple effects are also beginning to reach the world of user interfaces. Products like v0 (Vercel), Lovable, or Galileo AI are transforming the UI field, especially in rapid prototyping and iteration cases. 

Could we use AI to build user interfaces for tens of thousands of customers? Could we create production-ready user interfaces in less than a minute? What is the future of UI and design? How does SAP approach the problem of UI generation?

We will find answers to these complex but essential questions. 

The Status Quo ‚Äì problems with UI and where traditional approaches fail 

Today, most development teams at large enterprises choose between two approaches for UI:

  1. Hand-coded UI (HTML/CSS/JS/React, etc.) ‚Äì complete control and top-tier performance/accessibility, but slow, designer-dependent, and hard to keep on schedule when scope shifts. 

  2. No-code & low-code builders (SAP Build Work Zone, Bubble, Wix) ‚Äì faster and less technical, yet they lock you into auto-generated code, hurt scalability/integration, and limit customization. 

Here are some major pain points developers face when designing a UI using the first approach (hand-coded): 

  • Design gaps & inconsistency: non-designers copy-paste styles, creating a mismatched look and feel. 

  • Slow, siloed workflow: every tweak bounces between design, development, and QA. 

  • Poor usability: unclear flows complicate tasks for users. 

  • Fragmented standards: missing design systems introduce visual/behavioral drift. 

  • Weak SEO: sloppy markup and absent metadata/discoverability.

What if we could prevent these tradeoffs? Let‚Äôs briefly examine our existing team‚Äôs work, the SAP Build Work Zone, and the Builder tool.

Introducing SAP Build Work Zone 

SAP Build Work Zone is a digital experience platform that enables organizations to create personalized, role-based access to business applications, processes, and content‚Äîall from a single unified interface. It uses a no-code solution with a drag-and-drop interface for website design. 

Specifically, Work Zone utilizes a grid system for website layout and widgets (tiles, cards, text, search, rotating banner, etc.) to customize your website. Here is an example of an already live SAP Build Work Zone website:


Here you can see the editor window: 

What if you could design these user interfaces without requiring drag-and-drop or code? Could you create these webpages using natural language (NL) and text? Could it be completed within a minute or less? We invite you to explore our solution to the problem: the UI Builder and the team behind it.

 Our team & SAP Build Work Zone UI Builder 

We are a Research and Innovation team and we‚Äôre excited to introduce one of our prototypes, SAP Build Work Zone UI Builder, a tool designed to bring intelligent assistance and enhanced productivity to UI development within SAP Build Work Zone.

The Builder is an intelligent assistant that helps users create compliant, visually consistent websites within SAP Build Workzone using natural language. It describes the widgets you want to have (carousels, cards, images) and the use case (forum, FAQ page, representational website, etc.).

The Builder works like this: 

  1. Users would visit a website. 
  2. In the text field, the user would enter a prompt: Build a team website for research and innovation for discussion and documentation
  3. You would get a generated UI template like this: 

The generated template has different widgets in place to implement the described use case: search, welcome banner, quick links, and history. 

If you want to see it in action, check out this video presentation by our team: https://video.sap.com/media/t/1_6mt84kct.

What about the Future?

As a famous computer scientist named Alan Kay said, ‚ÄúThe best way to predict the future is to invent it.‚Äù  Inspired by this mindset, we see multiple paths to expanding and evolving our solution beyond its current capabilities. We could improve the project through features such as:  

  • Visual Prompting. Create user interfaces from images or hand-written notes.  
  • Multi-language support: German, Spanish, or French.  
  • Agents. One agent could understand user needs, another generates a template, and the last applies accessibility and responsiveness.  
  • Interactive conversations. They would allow edits and improvements to the generated template. 

Let‚Äôs also discuss scale and impact. The potential to scale it beyond SAP is enormous. According to Siteefy, roughly 252,000 new websites come online every day‚Äîthat is almost 92 million websites a year!

General benefits for small and large companies are huge: weeks of developer time redeemed, employee productivity increased through better design and faster iteration, and long-term maintenance costs cut by shipping clean, standards-compliant code from day one. These advantages empower businesses to scale efficiently and stay competitive in a rapidly evolving AI landscape.

entry.title: Getting Started with Joule Studio in SAP Build - Part 3: Integrate Joule Skills with Work Zone Sites
entry.content:
Disclaimer: The insights shared in this blog are based on my personal observations and learning. They may not apply universally, and I encourage readers to conduct their own research and make an informed decision before using this content for productive use.

In Last Part of this series, we covered how to create a skill, consume public APIs and deploying it for consumption.

In this guide, we will walk through the process of creating a custom skill related to a specific application (a CAP based Fiori application in this case), deploying it, and finally enabling Joule in SAP Build Work Zone.

Develop and Deploy Joule Skills for a Custom Application.

Step-by-Step Process:

  • Create a Destination in SAP BTP Subaccount where Joule Studio is subscribed ‚Äì pointing to the endpoint of your CAP service
  • Make sure sap.processautomation.enabled is set to true in additional properties for it to be consumed in SAP Build

 

 

  • Add Destination into the Control Tower section

 

  • Select Action section and Click Create to start a new action project.

 

  • Select SAP Cloud Application Programming Model as your action will have to point to a SAP Cloud Application Programming Model Service.

 

  • This lists down all possible service calls available

 

  • Select required endpoint and configure it.

 

 

  • Click Create, then select the Joule Skill tile and follow steps as per the previous blog in series - Getting Started with Joule Studio in SAP Build - P... - SAP Community

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

  • Save, release, and deploy the skill to your environment.

 

  • If you want your skills to be accessible globally from the work zone site, enable the shared environment property. Else, these skills will be available only on a standalone assistant.

 

 

Integrate Joule with Work zone

  • Under Formations in Global Account level, Click Include systems and select SAP Build Work Zone from required Subaccount

 

  • Select both Enable Capability Deployment and Enable Joule Icon in Integrated System

 

  • Complete the wizard by clicking Include

 

  • Once complete, navigate to System Landscape ‚Üí Formation.

 

 

  • Login to your work zone

 

  • Select Required Site and click on Settings icon

 

  • You should now be seeing property to Enable/Disable Joule. Enable the Joule property.

 

 

  • Open your site and you should be seeing the Joule Icon at the top

 

  • Test your deployed skills by prompting your query

 

 

 

 

Conclusion:

By integrating Joule Skills with SAP Build Work Zone, you bring intelligent assistance directly into your business applications. This part of the series demonstrated how to connect a CAP-based Fiori application, configure destinations, and deploy skills for real-time use within Work Zone.

With these steps, you empower users to interact with enterprise data and processes seamlessly using natural language‚Äîmaking your applications not just smarter, but more user-centric.

entry.title: Getting Started with Joule Studio in SAP Build ‚Äì Part 4: Managing Access to Custom Joule Skills
entry.content:
Disclaimer: The insights shared in this blog are based on my personal observations and learning. They may not apply universally, and I encourage readers to conduct their own research and make an informed decision before using this content for productive use.

In the previous part of this series, we demonstrated how to build and deploy custom Joule Skills and integrate them into SAP Build Work Zone sites. However, a critical aspect of deploying these skills in a real-world environment is access control deciding who can use your custom skills and how to share them securely.

By default, only users who are explicitly granted Execute or Admin access in the shared environment can consume your deployed Joule Skills. If other users attempt to interact with the skill, they receive a generic fallback response from Joule, which doesn't reflect the actual skill functionality.

 

Let‚Äôs walk through how to share your Joule Skills securely and effectively using SAP Build and SAP Cloud Identity Services.

Understanding the Access Control Behaviour

SAP Build's environment sharing works as follows:

  • You can share a project with up to 10 user groups or 5 individual users.
  • You cannot mix individual users and groups; if you do, only groups will be considered.
  • The access types available are:
    • Execute ‚Äì Allows users to use the deployed skill
    • Admin ‚Äì Full access to manage the environment

Option 1: Open Access for Everyone

If your use case allows, you can make the skill available to all users within your organization:

  • Go to the shared environment in SAP Build.
  • Click on Share ‚Üí Set General Access to Everyone with access: Execute.

 

This method makes the skill available to all users with access to the environment. Use with caution if the skill exposes sensitive operations or data.

Option 2: Controlled Access Using User Groups

For better governance and security, use user groups from your Cloud Identity Services (CIS) tenant:

  • Create a User Group in your IAS (Cloud Identity) tenant.

 

  • Assign the required users to this group (those who should have access to the skill).

 

  • In SAP Build, open the shared environment of your custom Joule Skill.

 

  • Click Share, set Type to User Group, and enter the exact name of the group you created in IAS.
  • Set the appropriate authorization (Execute or Admin).

 

Refresh & Redeploy Access

Once you‚Äôve shared with user groups:

  • Navigate to the Joule tab inside the environment.
  • Click Refresh.

 

  • You‚Äôll see a message: ‚ÄúPlease redeploy the capability to refresh their access right.‚Äù
  • Click on ‚ÄúClick here to redeploy‚Äù to apply the new access configuration.

 

It may take a few minutes for the redeployment to complete. Use Refresh to monitor the status.

 

Final Verification

After successful redeployment:

  • The Launch button will become active again.

 

  • Users assigned to the user group can now consume the Joule Skill from the Work Zone site.
  • If any user still doesn‚Äôt see the expected response, try:
    • Clearing browser cookies
    • Using incognito/private mode for a fresh session

 

When users click Open from the response message, they will be directed to the associated application screen (if configured).

 

Conclusion

Access management is a vital step in rolling out custom Joule Skills at scale. Whether you want to expose your skill to all users or control access via user groups, SAP Build offers the flexibility to do both. Properly sharing and redeploying your skill ensures the right people get the right experience and keeps your environment secure and manageable.

entry.title: SAP UX Q3/2025 Update ‚Äì Part 1: AI, Joule, SAP Build Work Zone, SAP Mobile Start
entry.content:
This series of posts gives an overview of user experience innovations in the cloud from the last six months, covering our whole portfolio, such as AI and Joule, SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508, SAP SuccessFactors, as well as covering  innovations in our UI technologies for building great UX.

In this first post, we‚Äôll look at the latest cross-suite UX innovations, coming from Joule, SAP Work Zone and SAP Mobile Start.

Here are the links to the other posts in the series published so far:

  • Part 2: SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 and SAP Fiori Launchpad (generally available innovations).
  • Part 3: Beta AI Innovations in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508.
  • Part 4: SAP SuccessFactors (AI, Joule and More).
  • Part 5: SAP Ariba and SAP Fieldglass.
  • Part 6: SAP Customer Experience and SAP Concur.
  • Part 7: UI Design and Technology for Web and Mobile.

Before we get started: if you haven‚Äôt already seen them, do have a look at the overview of public cloud UX innovations I posted in Q1/2025 (parts 2 to 7 are linked in part 1):

  • SAP User Experience Q1/2025 Update ‚Äì Part 1: Many New Innovations Available (AI, Joule and More).

This upcoming series of posts includes Joule and AI UX highlights from individual products within the SAP Business Suite, but for a more comprehensive overview of our recent AI innovations, not just UX related, have a look at:

  • SAP Business AI: Release Highlights Q2 2025.
  • SAP Sapphire Innovation Guide ‚Äì SAP Business AI.

 

Joule User Experience Innovations

Joule is the AI-powered copilot for SAP systems, offering a powerful new user experience, using natural language to access our cloud products and providing a seamless flow for the user wherever they are, on desktop, laptop or mobile devices.

First, we‚Äôll have a look at the latest generic or cross-product UX innovations, before I give you some pointers to the product-specific innovations as well as news about developing custom capabilities.

Cross-Product Joule UX Innovations

This section covers these user experience innovations:

  • Joule Analytical Pattern.
  • Joule supports multiple conversations.
  • Use Joule in 11 languages.
  • Joule stand-alone: Joule for Consultants
  • Joule in Microsoft 365 Copilot and Microsoft Teams
  • Joule Agents.

Joule Analytical Pattern

This new pattern is available in all products which give users access to our Joule copilot. This new pattern is powered by SAP Analytics Cloud, with data from models that are indexed by the Just Ask feature of SAP Analytics Cloud.

Figure 1: Example Joule Analytical Pattern. Alt Text: an animated GIF showing how a user asks Joule ‚ÄúShow me sales commission by agend for model bike sales‚Äù, and how Joule shows a horizontal bar chart for top 5 sales commissions per sales agent.

As you can see in figure 1, users can now access analytical insights from the product they are working in, without having to first navigate to SAP Analytics Cloud, making work more efficient and hence also more enjoyable.

The example in figure 1 is what we call a descriptive question, but Joule can respond to a wide range of queries:

  • Descriptive questions, such as ‚ÄúWhat is the total revenue for Q1?‚Äù or ‚ÄúShow me sales by region in 2025‚Äù.
  • Comparative analysis, such as ‚ÄúCompare sales between 2023 and 2024" Or How do profits in Germany compare to France?‚Äù
  • Time series analysis, such as ‚ÄúShow me sales by month‚Äù or ‚ÄúShow the trend of customer acquisitions over the last 6 months‚Äù.
  • Top / Bottom N analysis, such as ‚ÄúShow me top 5 sales by store‚Äù or ‚ÄúList the bottom 3 regions in terms of sales‚Äù.

Find out more in this blog post:

  • Introducing Analytical Insights in Joule: Empowering Smarter Decisions, Instantly.

With the introduction of this new pattern, Joule now supports four interaction patterns:

  1. Informational pattern, for querying written documents, such as SAP documentation in the SAP Help Portal, or customer policies etc.
  2. Navigational pattern, for finding and navigating to applications.
  3. Transactional pattern, for interacting directly with business applications.
  4. Analytical pattern, for answering analytical queries directly in Joule.

Joule Supports Multiple Conversations

When having a conversation with Joule, you can ask follow-up questions, building on the previous questions and answers in the conversation, since Joule keeps the context.

Now you can initiate up to ten conversations in parallel, with Joule keeping the context for each of the conversations, so that when you return to a previous conversation you can continue where you left off. Figure 2 shows what this looks like.

 

Figure 2: Joule supports multiple conversations. On the left, a conversation was started by asking ‚ÄúHow many languages does Joule support‚Äù. On the right, you see how active and expired conversations are shown. Alt Text: On the left, Joule replies with ‚ÄúJoule currently supports eleven language officially‚Äù and then lists them, below the answer a link to the source document ‚ÄúJoule Multi Language Support‚Äù is provided. On the right, the conversation history sidebar is visible on the left, overlaying half the screen, with a button ‚Äú+ New Conversation‚Äù at the top, followed by a section ‚ÄúActive‚Äù with two conversations and a sectin ‚ÄúExpired‚Äù with four. The bottom contains a link to ‚ÄúSettings‚Äù and on to ‚ÄúAI Notice‚Äù.

You can return to conversations within 8 hours. To start a new conversation, simply click on ‚ÄúNew Conversation‚Äù. The old conversation will be listed in the ‚ÄúActive‚Äù section, as you can see in Figure 2. The title of the conversation is automatically created by Joule using AI; users can rename the titles when they return to the conversation.  Joule supports a maximum of 10 active conversations.

After 8 hours, the conversation expires but is not deleted. It is kept read-only in the ‚ÄúExpired‚Äù section, as shown in Figure 2. Conversations are finally deleted 7 days after the creation date.

In the browser, Joule can be expanded to fill the screen, as shown in Figure 3.

Figure 3: Joule expanded to full-screen mode, showing the conversation history sidebar and the chat side by side. Alt Text: The same information is shown as on both screens of Figure 2, since the conversation history sidebar does not overlay the chat, and the chat is shown on the right with much more screen width.

Find out more in the documentation:

  • Using the Joule Web Client.

Use Joule in 11 Languages

Figure 3 shows that you can ask Joule which languages it supports, and it will answer with the list of 11 languages. Here they are in alphabetical order, with the variant of the language in brackets.

  • Chinese (Simplified)
  • English (US)
  • French (France)
  • German (Germany)
  • Greek
  • Japanese
  • Korean
  • Polish
  • Portugese (Brazil)
  • Spanish (Spain)
  • Vietnamese

Joule Stand-alone ‚Äì Joule for Consultants

In addition to providing Joule embedded in our products, we have a design pattern called Joule stand-alone, which we use for Joule for Consultants. With this pattern, Joule can be started directly, without first opening an SAP product and then opening Joule via the icon in the shell header. Joule stand-alone is opened in full screen, as shown in Figure 4.

Figure 4: Joule for Consultants using the Joule stand-alone pattern. Alt-Text: Joule full-screen, with one active conversation ‚ÄúCan you explaine about SAP Clean Core‚Äù, followed by a comprehensive answer, and scrolling options for reading the entire text‚Äù.

By supporting this pattern, people can open up Joule for Consultants directly and start asking questions about implementing or extending SAP products. Since in this case Joule is stand-alone, as the name suggests, the conversations you have there are not visible in the Joule instance that is embedded in our products, and vice-versa.

Joule in Microsoft 365 Copilot and Microsoft Teams

How often have you been in a chat with a colleague and needed to find some information from an SAP system? Up until now this would involve you leaving the chat, going to a different window and navigating to the right SAP application to get what were looking for.

Now, you can chat directly with Joule in Microsoft Teams, use Joule in Microsoft Teams and Microsoft Teams Mobile as an app, and ask Joule questions directly in Microsoft 365 Copilot. To get an idea of how powerful this is, watch this video:

To get started, have a look at the documentation:

  • Integrating Joule with Microsoft 365 Copilot

Joule Agents
